Vol. XXXIV, No. 34

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 28, 1930

JAY FIVE DEFEATS
CATHOLIC UNIV.

RIFLE TEAM CONQUERS BOONEVILLE
MILITARY ACADEMY BY CLOSE SCORE

Hopkins Vanquishes Washington Rival for Second Time
PASSAREW PLAYS WELL
Wood Has Keen Eye for Rival
Basket
The Jay basketers defeated Catholic University of Washington for
the second time at Carlin's Park
Wednesday night. The home team
was able to perform successfully regardless of the fact that they were
without the services of Gene Debuskey and Fritz Stude, who are
both out of the game for the remainder of the season, that is for
the one remaining game with
Georgetown tomorrow.

DR. FEISE TO TALK
ON GERMAN DRAMA
Tonight at 8.15, Prof.
Ernst Feise will lecture in the
Playshop on the "German Impressionistic Dram a.'..' Dr.
Feise will speak with special
reference to the series of plays
to be presented at the Playshop next Monday. This lecture is open to the public.
these plays are "Living
Hours," by Arthur Schnizler ; "Der Tod Und Der Tor,"
by Hugo von Hoffmannstahl,
and "The Tenor," by Franz
Wedekin.

LACROSSE AND TRACK
PRACTICE UNDER WAY

First Half

Walsh,. star guard for the Washingtonians, scored about two minutes after the opening whistle.
Wood retaliated with a field goal
and White with a foul• for Hopkins,. Passarew dropped a long shot
and Walsh scored for Catholic U.
Oliver dropped a foul for the visitors but Wood came back with two
more double-deckers for - the Jays.
Captain Passarew soon accounted
for two field goals and a foul, and
White and Wood both scored on
long shots bringing the half to a
close with Hopkins thirteen points
in the lead, the score standing 18-5.
Second Half

Walsh started off second fracas
with another field goal for Catholic University and Oliver added a
foul for the Washingtonians. Passarew and White scored from the
foul line. Wood dropped a long
shot and Passarew dribbled the
length of the floor to lift one
through the netting. The score now
stood at 24-8 in favor of the Black
and Blue. Then Walsh and Piefer
each accounted for two points, but
Passarew came back with another
pretty goal. At this point Dailey
substituted Heintzerling for White.
Peifer scored for Catholic U. The
Jays were not following up their
shots.well this half. Peifer was removed via the four-personal-foul
route. Passarew dropped a foul
and Rosenberg went in for Seigel.
Walsh Shows Form

Walsh scored a goal and two
fouls bringing the score to 26-20.
Howeved this is as close as the Capital City five came within tying the
Blue, for George Dailey rushed
Siegel and White back into the
fray. Gunnett scored with a free
throw for Hopkins, but O'Brien
matched this one for the visitors.
Gunnett tapped back a rebound for
two more points, but Walsh again
tallied for Catholic U. Siegel scored
from under the basket and Gunnett made two foul shots good. The
Jays missed five successive shots
from under the basket. Siegel
scored on a long throw. Hanley
and Walsh scored with fouls before the final whistle, at which time
the score was 35-25 in favor of
Hopkins.

Morrill, "Father Bill", and
Coach Van Orman Present
At Practice
TRACK MEET APRIL 12
Practice Daily at Four-thirty
More Men Needed
Lacrosse practice started Monday and has continued straight
through the week. Although the
turnout did not exceed 60 men including some of last year's team
The coach expects that the next
week will bring a bigger crowd out,
for the weather is favorable and
equipment is being collected to supply the needs of the candidates.
Next week Kelso Morrell will
start the men on the attack and
some other men will start the defense. "Father Bill," who was out
to the past week's practices, and is
supervising the coaching, is pleased
with the looks of the men who have
turned out thus far.
More Candidates Wanted

Since the schedule for this year
is a tough one, it is necessary to
have a good crowd out so that the
pick of the school may be chosen
for the team. Also the school has to
prepare for the 1932 Olympics,
which games are the goal of many
schools that were not entered last
year.
Besides the coach's call for candidates for practice every afternoon
at 4.30 o'clock, Manager Skutch is
issuing a call for managers and requests some of the candidates to
bring their own equipment, if possible.
Track Practice

This article was inspired by the
fact that the Johns Hopkins Rifle
Team emulating the example of
the football team has finally won a
match. They have been competing
with anywheres from two to six
other colleges every week but so
far the local marksmen have been
rather outshot.
The college to fall before the onslaughts of the J. H. U. riflemen
was the Kemper Military Academy,
located sO •the map informs us at
Booneville, Mo., the supposed home
of one Daniel Boone. The score
probably does not indicate the fierce
struggle undergone to win this single victory. Hopkins shot a total of
,228 while K. M. A. shot only 1874
so that undoubtedly we won.
The sergeant voiced a faint suspicion that there was a mistake and
that the K. M. A. men fired only
five rounds on each target instead of
ten as is the local custom, and unlerstanding. Needless to say this is
only a rumor and is probably quite
unfounded.
Reasons for the local teams easy
supremacy in this match may be laid
to the intense interest manifested in
this activity this year as compared
to former years. Statistics as corn)iled show that there is a membership of 64 men in the club, an in-

Varsity Swimmers
Meet Geo. Washington
According to Gutman, Freshman
manager of the swimming team, the
next meet will be with George
Washington University at the
Washington pool. This will be the
third meet of the season and will
be held next Saturday, March 1.
The other two meets, with Delaware and the Y. M. C. A., were
lost by large margins. Captain Jack
Stewart will be lost to the team
for the next meet and possibly the
rest of the season because of an injured hand. The team, however,
has been strengthened by the addition of Bud Frey, a former luminary of Friends' School. Frey who
looks to be good material, is expected to develop into a good swimmer, and his work is expected to
boost the team immensely.
The main weakness of the team is
the lack of divers. The only diver
on the team graduates this year.
Any men who know anything about
swimming should go out for the
team.

Hullabaloo Staff Calls
For Senior Write-ups

Track practice also started officially on Monday afternoon, although a number of men had started informal practice about a week
before to get limbered up for the
opening.
Scheid, manager of the track
team, is issuing a call for candidates
as two of last year's letter men have
been blacklisted and Schiebel will
not be able to run. The prospects
of the track team look hopeful
since nine letter men of last year
have turned out along with some
other excellent material.

The Hullabaloo staff is rapidly
accumulating its material in an effort to make early production of
the year book possible. However,
this can not be completed without
the cooperation of the Seniors
themselves. There are as yet a number of write-ups which are still at
large and the editor of the department wishes to make a personal appeal to these men to get their copy
in as soon as possible.
The other departments of the
book issue favorable reports of the
progress and substance of their
The first meet takes place .April work.
12, against Gettysburg.

Literary Conference
The Tau Beta Pi fraternity last

end of this week but no definite day
has been set. This number will be
a travel number with a cover arranged by Bloom.
Ever since the girl number of
he Blue Jay, there seems to be a

of a series of literary-supper conferences. Both graduate and active
members were present at the initial
meeting.
Lewis Marks opened the literary
period of the gathering with a discourse on the "Four Golden Keys
To Success." Karl Flocks followed
the first speaker, speaking on the
"Dress of the Centuries," while this
topic in turn was succeeded by the
"Romance of the Machine," as
presented by Robert Romoser.

crease of 23.1 per cent over the
membership of last year. Fifteen
thousand more rounds of ammunition has been used this year than
was used last year.
On the other hand, for some
strange reason the mortality of
electric bulbs has shown a marked
decrease. Two years ago 45 bulbs
were broken; last year six were
broken; and to date this year none
have been broken. The year we
might add is not up yet however.
Some of the club members have
intimated that lady members would
be welcome. Just what the genial
sergeant presiding over the range
would do if such were to present
themselves and ask for a few'blank
targets is unknown.

DANCE TO BE HELD
IN DORM TONIGHT
Tonight, a Dorm Dance will
be held in the Alumni Memorial Hall from 9 to 2 a. m.
Tickets may be procured from
Mike Romano at the price of
$1.25 per couple or stag. His
postoffice box is 1025.
Many Dorm students have
voiced their intentions of attending the dance and all
other students are invited to
attend. This promises to be
ne of the most colorful
dances of this year. Steinwalds band supplies the music.

AGENTS IN THE PRINCIPAL CITIES OF THE UNITED STATES
The answer may be found in the fact that Americans of all classes look
upon an A. B. degree not as a luxury (which it is), but as a necessity.
We have placed the A. B. on a pedestal and reverence it as a symbol
of attainment or of intelligence. No honest man who has completed
four years of college can look upon the degree as a work either of
attainment or of intelligence. For the amount of work required for
the degree when spread over a period of four years is negligible and
the difficulty of the work has been cut down to a minimum wherever
possible.
The whole story of the college loafer is then, a boy who is led into
with its beautiful
college by an erroneous sentiment and a man who has discovered his
error without the courage to correct it.

WORKERS
F then the A. B. degree may be gained without unusual application,
where are the real college workers? They are not the men neces,
sarily who receive very high grades, since a man may only do the average amount of work, but, being brilliant, receives good grades.
The college worker is the man who labors assiduously to acquire
information whether or not he receives any concrete reward for his
effort. The man who does a great deal of outside reading which is
not required, who spends extra hours in laboratories without the
knowledge of his professors, or who takes courses which he does not
need for the degree is the true college worker.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 28, 1930

DORM DOINGS

WEN'

With the continued balmy and refreshing days of the first manifestations of the approach of spring,
the students of the dormitory have
been exhibiting far more activity
than usual. The early part of the
week was witness to a rare game of
marbles within the precints of the
sacred court by several more learned of the inmates, namely a Sophomore and Junior. The fascinating
amusement was in progress with
golf balls as marbles, but after several perforations of various and
sundry windows, the sport was
switched to the game of golf itself.
A two-hole course was rapidly constructed in the midst of the lawn
equipped with all the necessary obstacles as bunkers and traps, the
former being furnished by odd bits
of clothing, while the latter was furnished by a few holes deftly scooped in the turf. Needless to say, the
whole course was entirely fairway,
no out-of-bound limits were established unless the ball chanced to
wander within the environs of Gilman Hall. At present a horse-shoe
range, or whatever the correct
cognomen maybe, is being organized
and all contributions for horseshoes will be gladly and graciously
received by any of the students in
the hall.
Recently, in order to hold the
dignity of the stately hall, one of
the Dorm representatives, .suffering from the stimulating effects of
spring fever, challenged the victim,
his chief grudge of the moment to
mortal combat on the field of honor.
A referee was selected, and seconds
appointed to mop up the pools of
blood and carry off the bodies after
the mortal combat. At first cream
puffs at twenty paces was suggested,
but as this was an affair of state,
this means was deemed insufficient.
The challenge was made orally within the solid walls of Remsen Hall,
but in order to save the concrete and
brick structure and save the janitor some work, it was decided that
the bout should be in back of the
hall on solid ground.
Witnesses assembled rapidly, and
at the sound of the clock in Gilman
Hall, the champions entered the
arena with blood in their eyes.
Cheers shook the ground as they approached each other in preparation
for the initial blow was to start the
battle of the centuries. Sock! And
the fight was concluded. Both conquerers stalked off the field in utter contentment and retired to their
respective abodes satisfied that the
day was successful and well worth
while.

CHEMISTRY AND FURNISHINGS

To Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Centuries ago when science was
a field of mystery, the chemistry
laboratory was the essence of all
that was magic and evil. The term
brought with it the picture of a
small, . gloomy chamber, meagerly
furnished, seeking with innumerable cobwebs, curiously shaped vessels, potent powders, phials, and
magic spells. Barely outlined against
the dark shadows an emaciated,
stoopshouldered old man potters
among his unholy implements.
From his eyes shines the cruel unearthly look of a madman. He is always at work devising new and better means for his devilish practices.
Development and education has
gradually altered the picture. We
think now of a laboratory as a clean,
well ventilated, spacious room
where white clad bright looking
young men are continually cleaning
test-tubes and doing Other difficult
tasks for the advancement of science, the uplift of society and big
business. Practically everything has
been done to promote efficiency but
one—comfort.
Of all the necessities of decent
existence, the powers that hold
sway over Hopkins laboratories
have with held the chairs. Imagine
the suffering which a poor flatfooted or otherwise handicapped
student must undergo. For three
solid hours he must chafe his corns
and bunions—sometimes only to
watch something filter or boil for
two hours. He must disentangle and
put to memory innumerable formullas and reactions. He must set
up intricate apparatus. He must
remember countless materials. Tired
in mind the student must be, but
why tired in body?
Years ago, rumor has it, a few
chairs were to be found in the inorganic laboratory, but now not a single one remains, not even for those
students with serious physical handicaps.

If I were a Prof., I would be
sociable. Friendship with and confidence of a class tend for the greatest academic advancement. I would
encourage familiarity and invite
students to informal conferences
from time to time, in order to remove obstructions from the paths of
their study. I would try to act as a
sort of composite father and brother to my students, to be able to correctly advise them on the problems
of life at any time. I would take a
personal interest in my course, and
try to make it as interesting as possible, both from the viewpoint of
lecturer and audience. I'd cut unappreciated theory down to a skeleton,
and catch the growing youth's interest in the practises of today's
world.

LIBRARY CHANGES EXCITE VARIED
COMMENT AMONG STUDENTS HERE
It's bad enough to have summer
on the campus in February, students seem to think, without the
added trouble of there being no curtains to intercept the sun's rays in
the library reading room. Relief is
definitely promised, however, not by
the weather man but by the library
authorities. The relief takes the
form not of more seasonable weather—for even library officials can't
arrange that—but of suitable drapery for the naked loveliness of the
recently decorated windows. The
exact nature of the drapes and the
time of their arrival have not been
disclosed.
Another library feature that has
caused much and varied comment
on the campus during the past week
is the dismantling of the opaque
glass partitions that have long individualized the tables in the main
reading room. They were removed
to permit shifting of the tables for
the reception and exhibition on
Commemoration Day, and it has
been decided that they shall remain
off. With the glass slabs go the
little ledges, or arm-rests, that ran
along the bottom of the glass in the
plane with the table tops. The
natural result is that the room
Seems more open and spacious, and
less long and narrow than the
longitudinal partitions made it appear formerly.
The library staff seem to think
the change is an improvement, but
it is far otherwise with the students. Some object to it on aesthetic
grounds, others for purely practical
considerations. Nor is there unanimity in disapproving the attraction. Some have expressed themselves in favor of the new order.
Aesthetic reasons, incidentally, are
advanced in behalf of the change. It
seems to have been felt that the old
opaque glass clashed with the general aspect of the reading room after
its recent renovation.

you sit next to pests and know it,

PASSAREW PLAYS WELL
Wood Has Keen Eye for Rival
Basket
The Jay basketers defeated Catholic University of Washington for
the second time at Carlin's Park
Wednesday night. The home team
was able to perform successfully regardless of the fact that they were
without the services of Gene Debuskey and Fritz Stude, who are
both out of the game for the remainder of the season, that is for
the one remaining game with
Georgetown tomorrow.

DR. FEISE TO TALK
ON GERMAN DRAMA
Tonight at 8.15, Prof.
Ernst Feise will lecture in the
Playshop on the "German Impressionistic Dram a.'..' Dr.
Feise will speak with special
reference to the series of plays
to be presented at the Playshop next Monday. This lecture is open to the public.
these plays are "Living
Hours," by Arthur Schnizler ; "Der Tod Und Der Tor,"
by Hugo von Hoffmannstahl,
and "The Tenor," by Franz
Wedekin.

LACROSSE AND TRACK
PRACTICE UNDER WAY

First Half

Walsh,. star guard for the Washingtonians, scored about two minutes after the opening whistle.
Wood retaliated with a field goal
and White with a foul• for Hopkins,. Passarew dropped a long shot
and Walsh scored for Catholic U.
Oliver dropped a foul for the visitors but Wood came back with two
more double-deckers for - the Jays.
Captain Passarew soon accounted
for two field goals and a foul, and
White and Wood both scored on
long shots bringing the half to a
close with Hopkins thirteen points
in the lead, the score standing 18-5.
Second Half

Walsh started off second fracas
with another field goal for Catholic University and Oliver added a
foul for the Washingtonians. Passarew and White scored from the
foul line. Wood dropped a long
shot and Passarew dribbled the
length of the floor to lift one
through the netting. The score now
stood at 24-8 in favor of the Black
and Blue. Then Walsh and Piefer
each accounted for two points, but
Passarew came back with another
pretty goal. At this point Dailey
substituted Heintzerling for White.
Peifer scored for Catholic U. The
Jays were not following up their
shots.well this half. Peifer was removed via the four-personal-foul
route. Passarew dropped a foul
and Rosenberg went in for Seigel.
Walsh Shows Form

Walsh scored a goal and two
fouls bringing the score to 26-20.
Howeved this is as close as the Capital City five came within tying the
Blue, for George Dailey rushed
Siegel and White back into the
fray. Gunnett scored with a free
throw for Hopkins, but O'Brien
matched this one for the visitors.
Gunnett tapped back a rebound for
two more points, but Walsh again
tallied for Catholic U. Siegel scored
from under the basket and Gunnett made two foul shots good. The
Jays missed five successive shots
from under the basket. Siegel
scored on a long throw. Hanley
and Walsh scored with fouls before the final whistle, at which time
the score was 35-25 in favor of
Hopkins.

Lacrosse practice started Monday and has continued straight
through the week. Although the

The coach expects that the next
week will bring a bigger crowd out,
for the weather is favorable and
equipment is being collected to supply the needs of the candidates.
Next week Kelso Morrell will
start the men on the attack and
some other men will start the defense. "Father Bill," who was out
to the past week's practices, and is
supervising the coaching, is pleased
with the looks of the men who have
turned out thus far.
More Candidates Wanted

Since the schedule for this year
is a tough one, it is necessary to
have a good crowd out so that the
pick of the school may be chosen
for the team. Also the school has to
prepare for the 1932 Olympics,
which games are the goal of many
schools that were not entered last
year.
Besides the coach's call for candidates for practice every afternoon
at 4.30 o'clock, Manager Skutch is
issuing a call for managers and requests some of the candidates to
bring their own equipment, if possible.

Varsity Swimmers
Meet Geo. Washington
According to Gutman, Freshman
manager of the swimming team, the
next meet will be with George
Washington University at the
Washington pool. This will be the
third meet of the season and will
be held next Saturday, March 1.
The other two meets, with Delaware and the Y. M. C. A., were
lost by large margins. Captain Jack
Stewart will be lost to the team
for the next meet and possibly the
rest of the season because of an injured hand. The team, however,
has been strengthened by the addition of Bud Frey, a former luminary of Friends' School. Frey who
looks to be good material, is expected to develop into a good swimmer, and his work is expected to
boost the team immensely.
The main weakness of the team is
the lack of divers. The only diver
on the team graduates this year.
Any men who know anything about
swimming should go out for the
team.

WORKERS
F then the A. B. degree may be gained without unusual application,
where are the real college workers? They are not the men neces,
sarily who receive very high grades, since a man may only do the average amount of work, but, being brilliant, receives good grades.
The college worker is the man who labors assiduously to acquire
information whether or not he receives any concrete reward for his
effort. The man who does a great deal of outside reading which is
not required, who spends extra hours in laboratories without the
knowledge of his professors, or who takes courses which he does not
need for the degree is the true college worker.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 28, 1930

DORM DOINGS

WEN'

With the continued balmy and refreshing days of the first manifestations of the approach of spring,
the students of the dormitory have
been exhibiting far more activity
than usual. The early part of the
week was witness to a rare game of
marbles within the precints of the
sacred court by several more learned of the inmates, namely a Sophomore and Junior. The fascinating
amusement was in progress with
golf balls as marbles, but after several perforations of various and
sundry windows, the sport was
switched to the game of golf itself.
A two-hole course was rapidly constructed in the midst of the lawn
equipped with all the necessary obstacles as bunkers and traps, the
former being furnished by odd bits
of clothing, while the latter was furnished by a few holes deftly scooped in the turf. Needless to say, the
whole course was entirely fairway,
no out-of-bound limits were established unless the ball chanced to
wander within the environs of Gilman Hall. At present a horse-shoe
range, or whatever the correct
cognomen maybe, is being organized
and all contributions for horseshoes will be gladly and graciously
received by any of the students in
the hall.
Recently, in order to hold the
dignity of the stately hall, one of
the Dorm representatives, .suffering from the stimulating effects of
spring fever, challenged the victim,
his chief grudge of the moment to
mortal combat on the field of honor.
A referee was selected, and seconds
appointed to mop up the pools of
blood and carry off the bodies after
the mortal combat. At first cream
puffs at twenty paces was suggested,
but as this was an affair of state,
this means was deemed insufficient.
The challenge was made orally within the solid walls of Remsen Hall,
but in order to save the concrete and
brick structure and save the janitor some work, it was decided that
the bout should be in back of the
hall on solid ground.
Witnesses assembled rapidly, and
at the sound of the clock in Gilman
Hall, the champions entered the
arena with blood in their eyes.
Cheers shook the ground as they approached each other in preparation
for the initial blow was to start the
battle of the centuries. Sock! And
the fight was concluded. Both conquerers stalked off the field in utter contentment and retired to their
respective abodes satisfied that the
day was successful and well worth
while.

By Harold B. Yudkin

CHEMISTRY AND FURNISHINGS

To Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Centuries ago when science was
a field of mystery, the chemistry
laboratory was the essence of all
that was magic and evil. The term
brought with it the picture of a
small, . gloomy chamber, meagerly
furnished, seeking with innumerable cobwebs, curiously shaped vessels, potent powders, phials, and
magic spells. Barely outlined against
the dark shadows an emaciated,
stoopshouldered old man potters
among his unholy implements.
From his eyes shines the cruel unearthly look of a madman. He is always at work devising new and better means for his devilish practices.
Development and education has
gradually altered the picture. We
think now of a laboratory as a clean,
well ventilated, spacious room
where white clad bright looking
young men are continually cleaning
test-tubes and doing Other difficult
tasks for the advancement of science, the uplift of society and big
business. Practically everything has
been done to promote efficiency but
one—comfort.
Of all the necessities of decent
existence, the powers that hold
sway over Hopkins laboratories
have with held the chairs. Imagine
the suffering which a poor flatfooted or otherwise handicapped
student must undergo. For three
solid hours he must chafe his corns
and bunions—sometimes only to
watch something filter or boil for
two hours. He must disentangle and
put to memory innumerable formullas and reactions. He must set
up intricate apparatus. He must
remember countless materials. Tired
in mind the student must be, but
why tired in body?
Years ago, rumor has it, a few
chairs were to be found in the inorganic laboratory, but now not a single one remains, not even for those
students with serious physical handicaps.

If I were a Prof., I would be
sociable. Friendship with and confidence of a class tend for the greatest academic advancement. I would
encourage familiarity and invite
students to informal conferences
from time to time, in order to remove obstructions from the paths of
their study. I would try to act as a
sort of composite father and brother to my students, to be able to correctly advise them on the problems
of life at any time. I would take a
personal interest in my course, and
try to make it as interesting as possible, both from the viewpoint of
lecturer and audience. I'd cut unappreciated theory down to a skeleton,
and catch the growing youth's interest in the practises of today's
world.

LIBRARY CHANGES EXCITE VARIED
COMMENT AMONG STUDENTS HERE
It's bad enough to have summer
on the campus in February, students seem to think, without the
added trouble of there being no curtains to intercept the sun's rays in
the library reading room. Relief is
definitely promised, however, not by
the weather man but by the library
authorities. The relief takes the
form not of more seasonable weather—for even library officials can't
arrange that—but of suitable drapery for the naked loveliness of the
recently decorated windows. The
exact nature of the drapes and the
time of their arrival have not been
disclosed.
Another library feature that has
caused much and varied comment
on the campus during the past week
is the dismantling of the opaque
glass partitions that have long individualized the tables in the main
reading room. They were removed
to permit shifting of the tables for
the reception and exhibition on
Commemoration Day, and it has
been decided that they shall remain
off. With the glass slabs go the
little ledges, or arm-rests, that ran
along the bottom of the glass in the
plane with the table tops. The
natural result is that the room
Seems more open and spacious, and
less long and narrow than the
longitudinal partitions made it appear formerly.
The library staff seem to think
the change is an improvement, but
it is far otherwise with the students. Some object to it on aesthetic
grounds, others for purely practical
considerations. Nor is there unanimity in disapproving the attraction. Some have expressed themselves in favor of the new order.
Aesthetic reasons, incidentally, are
advanced in behalf of the change. It
seems to have been felt that the old
opaque glass clashed with the general aspect of the reading room after
its recent renovation.

you sit next to pests and know it,
whereas in the past you could be

Cotillion Board
Dauce Tomorrow
The Cotillion Club wishes to announce a dance at Levering Hall
Oh March 1, tomorrow night. The
music will be furnished as usual by
Bob Iula's orchestra, and the dance
will begin at 9 o'clock. For the first
half of the year these dances were
held once a week regularly. However, now that more outside events
are going on the dances are being
held only once every two weeks.
It is requested that the couples
attending the dance come a little
bit earlier as lately no one has arrived until 9.30 or 10 o'clock. There
will be no door prize given out at
tomorrow night's dance.
